rename.from: Fullscreen not working for most resolutions on Mac OS X
rename.to: Fullscreen not working for most resolutions

body:
> The first issue is that not all possible resolutions are reported. Here's what the display really supports according to SwitchResX, which also allows setting those modes: [...]

FWIW those additional modes are not officially supported by OS X. I believe SwitchResX might be using private Apple APIs which will get Mac App Store apps rejected. ResXtreme does the same thing: http://resxtreme.com

The full screen window positioning part of this appears to be a bug. I will look into it.

As for what video modes are exposed, have a look at `modeIsGood`.

Also FWIW, I don't think there are any valid reasons for games to change the resolution nowadays. It's slow, bug-prone, messes up window and monitor viewport positions, makes application switching flaky and on OS X forces you to choose between disabling Cmd+Tab and messing up the desktop icons, all of which annoys users. If you want to render at a lower resolution, render to a texture. **Edit:** But that doesn't mean I won't fix bugs related to mode switching.

> Also FWIW, I don't think there are any valid reasons for games to change the resolution nowadays.

The only valid remaining reason should be if you're doing it in order to switch to another (higher) refresh rate. If that's not the goal (but rather the resolution change), then completely agreed.

Totally agree that switching the resolution is mostly bad and should be avoided. We strongly recommend that to our users. But since we also expose other modes reported by GLFW, we'd rather have it working for obvious reasons :)
Have been looking into this one and am officially stumped.

Have you tried a really old version of GLFW to see how it compares?

There's a chance this is a regression in OS X 10.11.3 since full screen resolutions that are not native resolution are used so seldomly these days.
A bisect says 6743761c2c3893f95125dfd12b28620b9cf3dfa5, unfortunately. Considering how old it is and how late 3.2 is, I won't consider this blocking but I'll keep working on this once 3.2 is out.

issue.title: glfwSetWindowMonitor broken

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Bug reports and bugfix pull requests

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
Restoring fullscreen mode to windowed mode does not respect the `glfwSetWindowMonitor` arguments.

GLFW 3.2.0 Cocoa NSGL chdir menubar retina dynamic (d97044d9acc0c76433edda5a75b3196957906ca5)
OS X 10.11.4
Intel Iris Graphics 6100
#### Details

While in fullscreen mode, calling `glfwSetWindowMonitor(window, NULL, xpos, ypos, width, height, 0);` does not result in a window at `xpos, ypos` with `width x height` dimensions, but rather covers the entire screen (like having double-clicked on the window title bar). Printing all events gives the following sequence:

```
BEFORE RESTORE to: 520,176 - 640 x 480
6.252: Window framebuffer resized to 3300 x 2002
6.253: Window resized to 1650 x 1001
6.256: Window framebuffer resized to 1650 x 1001
6.260: Window refreshed
6.270: Window framebuffer resized to 640 x 480
6.271: Window resized to 640 x 480
6.273: Window refreshed
AFTER RESTORE
6.277: Window framebuffer resized to 1680 x 1001
6.278: Window resized to 1680 x 1001
6.281: Window refreshed
6.310: Window framebuffer resized to 3360 x 2002
6.322: Window refreshed
```

A workaround seems to be:

``` c
glfwSetWindowMonitor(window, NULL, xpos, ypos, width, height, 0);
glfwPollEvents();
glfwSetWindowMonitor(window, NULL, xpos, ypos, width, height, 0);
```

I also randomly inserted a `_glfwPlatformPollEvents();` in `cocoa_window.m` after `_glfwInputWindowMonitorChange(window, monitor);` at line 1220. This also fixes the issue and produces the following output:

```
BEFORE RESTORE to: 520,176 - 640 x 480
    BEFORE INNER POLL EVENTS
11.455: Window moved to 0, 0
11.456: Window framebuffer resized to 3300 x 2100
11.459: Window refreshed
    AFTER INNER POLL EVENTS
11.510: Window framebuffer resized to 3300 x 2002
11.511: Window resized to 1650 x 1001
11.537: Window framebuffer resized to 3300 x 2002
11.547: Window refreshed
11.574: Window framebuffer resized to 1280 x 960
11.574: Window resized to 640 x 480
11.579: Window refreshed
AFTER RESTORE
```

Note also that, even though with the workarounds the window ends-up in the correct shape, window position events are missing.

body:
Does anybody know if this is fixed? Almost no fullscreen works for me on OSX 10.11 .
EDIT: I just tested this on 3.2 and 3.1.2 and the issue is the same on both, if the display mode is changed before entering fullscreen, nothing is displayed (or distorted shifted). Appears to be related to/duplicate of https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/748
@mokafolio It has not been fixed yet. Please use the desktop resolution, if possible.

This PR aims to fix #4141, #4142 and #4143.

I also added support to enable OpenGL debug message callbacks. Made debugging a lot easier.

Note: these changes do not fix fullscreen transitions on OS X (with Retina displays) - see https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/748 and https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/682.

issue.body:
I have a C++ codebase based on GLFW3 and OpenGL. I got it working on OSX 10.11 El Capitan on a Macbook Pro mid 2014. But now I got the new Macbook Pro 2016 !5" with the Intel HD Graphics 530 and the Radeon Pro 455, and I'm struggling to get to work. I'm also seeing som estrange behaviour with windows sizes and fullscreen.

I created the same example as here: http://www.glfw.org/docs/latest/quick.html
but with a bit more logging. I pushed it to here: https://github.com/Discordia/glfw-example

There is two lines for creating the window. The first one creates a window and the second one a full screen window. I alternate between them to test windowed or fullscreen mode.

Output in windowed mode is:
/<pth>/glfw-example/cmake-build-debug/glfw_example
Primary mode w: 1680, h: 1050, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 640, h: 480, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 840, h: 524, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 800, h: 600, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1024, h: 768, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1152, h: 720, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1280, h: 800, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1440, h: 900, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1650, h: 1050, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 2048, h: 1280, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 2560, h: 1600, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 2880, h: 1800, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 3360, h: 2100, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Framebuffer size w: 1280, h: 960
Initialized, GL Version: 2.1 ATI-1.48.21
Process finished with exit code 0

Notice that I'm asking for a 640x480 window but the frame buffer ends up being 1280x960.

Output in full screen is:
/<path>/glfw-example/cmake-build-debug/glfw_example
Primary mode w: 1680, h: 1050, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 640, h: 480, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 840, h: 524, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 800, h: 600, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1024, h: 768, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1152, h: 720, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1280, h: 800, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1440, h: 900, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 1650, h: 1050, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 2048, h: 1280, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 2560, h: 1600, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 2880, h: 1800, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Modes w: 3360, h: 2100, r: 8, g: 8, b: 8, refresh: 60
Framebuffer size w: 3360, h: 2100
Initialized, GL Version: 2.1 ATI-1.48.21
Process finished with exit code 0

Notice that the monitor primary mode is 1680x1050 (which seams strange), and the frame buffer ends up being 3360x2100 (which seams more reasonable).

The problem though is that it draws fine in windowed mode. A animated triangel with different color per vertex. In fullscreen the window is black. The only thing I change between runs is the forth argument to glfwCreateWindow. Either it's nullptr for windowed mode or it's the monitor pointer for fullscreen.

If I change the fullscreen line to:
window = glfwCreateWindow(3360, 2100, "Simple example", monitor, nullptr);
Then I actually see the animated triangle but in't not centered. It is spinning in the bottom half of the screen. Also the frame buffer is then reported as:
Framebuffer size w: 2560, h: 1600

If I change it to:
window = glfwCreateWindow(2560, 1600, "Simple example", monitor, nullptr);

I see just the tip of the spinning triangle at the bottom of the screen, most of it is outside. And the frame buffer is reported as:
Framebuffer size w: 2048, h: 1280

Isn't this strange.

body: I started on this again today and found it had been fixed already. A bisect points to 77a8f103d8f8519d1a723bbd8b0490b448f1f430. Turns out the fix was adding the (required but previously missing) context update on screen parameter change.
